comments.commentBody:
I agree about his not having a future.
It's not his that I am worried about but ours as in America, sometimes called erroneously as post-racial.
Mr. Z. will get lots of air time on Fox et al but there will always be a stigma of a selfimportant vigilante who shot an innocent 17 year old kid.

Zimmerman may have been acquitted by the jury, but in the minds of many people, myself included, he is guilty of murder.  It would have been better for him to have served some time in jail simply to make people feel that some kind of justice had been served and he could have moved on with his life without so much stigma.  Now he is considered a bully and a murderer who was set free by a white jury because of racism.  He doesn't face much of a future in this country.

The "man" was pursuing a 17yr old against the advice of the police while he was armed. The "man" probably tried to intimidate and frighten someone capable of fighting back. When the "man" was losing a fight he instigated, the "man" shot the "child". He claimed self-defense. He's never expressed any regret, nor suggested he would do anything different.

The jury made a decision based on evidence, but Zimmerman was allowed to make his case, while the "child" only got a hole in the ground.
True, our only solace is that Mr. Zimmerman has to live with this stupid decision for the rest of his life.
Yes he does, this is the history of America.

Justice HAS been served. Zimmerman should never have been charged and, had it not been for "Reverend Al", Jesse Jackson and Barack Obama, Trayvon would not have gotten his day in court that he surely did not deserve.

Zimmerman may have been acquitted by the jury, but in the minds of many people, myself included, he is guilty of murder.  It would have been better for him to have served some time in jail simply to make people feel that some kind of justice had been served and he could have moved on with his life without so much stigma.  Now he is considered a bully and a murderer who was set free by a white jury because of racism.  He doesn't face much of a future in this country.

The "man" was pursuing a 17yr old against the advice of the police while he was armed. The "man" probably tried to intimidate and frighten someone capable of fighting back. When the "man" was losing a fight he instigated, the "man" shot the "child". He claimed self-defense. He's never expressed any regret, nor suggested he would do anything different.

The jury made a decision based on evidence, but Zimmerman was allowed to make his case, while the "child" only got a hole in the ground.

Deb,

Having the information on that decision-making process makes a big difference. Well that, and also when you comment from that account, your photo shows up. :)

I will persist in my belief that a note which solvers may choose NOT to read is no spoiler for those who choose to leave it UNread, while still respecting you for bearing the burden of a decision, as I respect anyone who takes time to reach a decision with other people.

I will decide whether to continue solving electronically or begin wasting paper, since it appears that the Times will continue to keep the money we have all paid (regardless of solving method) while running puzzles that are more frustrating in some methods than in others.

Please inform Mr. Shortz that a man who has solved Times Crosswords since the Will Weng era expressed the view that customers have no entitlement to any particular level of gimmickry in puzzle construction; if software is provided to online customers for a price, they are paying for a system that should permit them to enter "correct" answers. If technological limitations impose a limit on what gimmick can be incorporated into crosswords, then so be it.

Mr. Weng and Mr. Maleska had technology that permitted only written entries on paper. Visible entries. Not aromas, not sounds, only writing. But within those limitations, they managed to provide puzzles that all solvers could attempt, using the technology provided.

Thanks and see you for the Monday,

-- MighTbeawayFriday

It's one thing to get your 'facts' from the leftist media, but if you'd watched the trial, every minute televised for us to make up our own minds, you could have seen for yourself. 4 minutes to get home...

After watching every witness, listening to every argument, it appears the jury did it's job correctly and found the Peruvian guy innocent.

It's one thing to get your 'facts' from the leftist media, but if you'd watched the trial, every minute televised for us to make up our own minds, you could have seen for yourself. 4 minutes to get home...

After watching every witness, listening to every argument, it appears the jury did it's job correctly and found the Peruvian guy innocent.

Dear Mr. John of Virginia,

I lived for ten years in Saudi Arabia, sir.

There I learned something about freedom of speech.

Specifically, I learned what it is like to live without it.

This same ideology, taken to the extreme, means Malala could only go to school at the risk of her life.

I see a sublime courage in Malala.

Very little courage is necessary for the sort of dialogue I see here, and indeed in most of modern American life. So many outsource their need for courage to others, and outsource their thinking to media chatterati.

But I call on all who post here to cherish Malala's courage, and reflect on whether they would have enough to do what she has done if threatened as she was.

It is a humbling thought, or should be.

People get away with murder all the time. Just get behind the wheel and mow 'em down, tell the judge you were on your cell phone or dropped your coffee and cheesecake, works every time here in New York.

People get away with murder all the time. Just get behind the wheel and mow 'em down, tell the judge you were on your cell phone or dropped your coffee and cheesecake, works every time here in New York.

When people complain about test prep, what they're describing isn't the teachers teaching reading or math. What they're describing is a situation in which the teachers realize their high-school-age students are walking into the classroom with grade-school skills, so they're forced to focus on prepping the kids to eliminate obviously wrong answers and guess among those that remain, to maximize their scores.

This doesn't happen unless the tests, which are only useful to estimate how much students know, are misused to evaluate the teachers or schools. In effect, we're asking the tests to tell us WHY students know something (or don't), and that's something they can't do. When there was no threat that schools would be shut down or teachers fired based on test scores, the high school teacher whose kids had elementary skills could focus on remediating those skills. Now, only the test scores matter, not the learning that they're supposed to represent.

To say nothing of the fact that student test scores depend on a number of factors, and parental factors are much more important than anything that happens in the school. It's not an accident that poor areas have "failing" schools and rich areas have "successful" schools, and it doesn't actually have much to do with the schools themselves.

No student ever benefited from practicing multiple choice tests ad nauseum, as those with weak sills often must..When you emphasize teaching to a test, something is lost; sadly it may be  a passion for literature or the sheer joy of learning.  Instead of writing creatively or  being exposed to poetry and great novels, our students are parsing everything from manuals to textbook chapters.

The problem come in where instead of TEACHING READING, they are testing it instead, giving preparatory tests and that sort of thing rather than actually giving them the education the kids need. If all the students are doing is taking test after prep-test after prep-test, where is the time to actually educate them to really KNOW the subjects well?

Give an end of the year test, if they pass, they move on to the next grade, if they dont, they either take summer school or do the grade over. Of course, the Administrations of these schools dont want themselves to look bad, it means down-checks on their OWN fitness reports, and so they 'pass' kids that have NOT had the learning experience that they should have had, they have been subjected to a series of CYA testing by the teachers and the School and District Admins, which means tons of money spent and yet little actual education given to the kids.

So many of the tests being multiple choice means that the kids have a pretty good random chance of passing anyways, whether they know the data or not, and if most of the 'possible answers' are so far out of the ballpark so as to highlight the true answer it does nothing for the kids except learn how to pass rigged tests.

Stop catering to the Admin at District and School level, give the money to the teachers and test only at the end of the semesters when it really can show progress or not, not wasting money on rigged tests to cover the butts of the too highly paid Admins to begin with

The common complaint that you here is that schools are substituting test preparation for instruction. I have no doubt that there may be problems with the tests; but if a test is properly designed to measure reading comprehension, I have never heard of any reasonable explanation of why teaching to the test is not in fact a very good idea. And if a test measures a students ability to solve basic math story problems, how can it possibly be that teaching to the test is a bad? Without testing you have no idea how the student, teacher, or school is performing. If there is a problem, it is not the concept of testing that is at fault, but rather the nature of the tests themselves.
We need to get to a situation where you just exchange your battery pack ... instant recharge!

The Chinese are definitely pricklish in the face of criticism, and not so very committed to free speech, so in the future you may not see the most objective reviews of Chinese products.  This particularly so for cars since car reviewers are known for taking a heavy hand in their criticisms, which is usually just fine.

Where were you? Every moment of this trial was televised, where was the evidence of 'stalking' ?

The hopes of the race industry rested on this one, they got their best and brightest involved but in the end the facts simply were not there. The jury (and millions of viewers) disagree with the idea the Peruvian guy was guilty of murder. The story we were told by the media simply wasn't true..

The Barrington Concours d'Elegance, in horsey Barrington, IL, will be Sunday the 14th of July at the Mackray C.C.  The featured marque is Voisin.

The museum at the Indianapolis Speeway owns the even rarer  W196 Streamliner, which they variously show when the spirit moves them.  Frankly, I almost passed out when I saw it sitting there amongst other, almost equally notable racers.

I can tell you from personal experience that you are wrong. I got rear ended at highway speeds on my Escape. 55 mph plus. Sure the cars were done, but barring a lifetime of back pain for me, and probably some neck related injuries to the other car's passengers, things were remarkably calm. And yes, the other was a car while mine was a SUV.

Physics of modern cars are not something you can imagine. The engineering is there, cars are safer, often the failure points are things like seat backs etc.

Toyota is just being lazy in the case of RAV4.

These high riding vehicles also don't perform so well for a car that rear ends them. A car hits the rear end and literally drives underneath these SUVs with nothing to stop the car except the windshield and/or occupants head(s). How many people have been killed because they rear ended and Rav4 or Jeep?
I know, this issue is another matter all together. One that should perhaps be saved for another article.
So what this person is saying is you can't have your cake and eat it too. Well, if that were true, wouldn't cars and the Subaru have failed this test? No, they didn't.

Take a look on Youtube for old crash tests. Those old, massive cars with long hoods might seem safer; but they are far from it.  As for repair costs, it's easier to replace a plastic-covered bumper and a straight beam than the carefully designed, chrome-laden front fascias of cars from the 1950s, 60s, and early 70s.   I suspect the reasons for high repair costs are economic and not related to engineering.

This test is like a sucker punch to the car: to meet CAFE standards, mfrs must trim every pound. They actually work to shave ounces off parts, totaling to pounds in the vehicle. Thus, due to CAFE (fuel economy standards) any vehicle can have only just enough structure to pass the various tests. This area wasn't tested previously, so an mfr adding weight there would be effectively penalized.

If you pull off the bumper cover on a new car, you'll see that outside the longitudinal beams (which replace the frame rails of decades ago) there's nothing but the wheel. Even a 5mph impact at a corner is now going to be a multi-thousand dollar repair.

Decades ago a car might have a six foot long hood and the bracing needed to hold up all that sheetmetal, so something would eventually absorb such a crash. But back then no one wore their seatbelts, so even if the car's structure aced the test that design work was wasted, as a person flying through the windshield typically doesn't enjoy the head-first landing on pavement.

The new test will add some safety, a little weight, and make working within the confined space underhood even more difficult. The alternative is to stretch the nose about six inches, allowing room for both extra bracing and for repair work, but you won't get that bc of CAFE.

Get rid of this" stand your ground law", there was no reason to use deadly force against this boy. More tragedies are bound to happen because of this law  I feel terribly sorry for this boy who lost his life and for his parents who had to through this trial. This is a crime . Justice was not served. this is a shocking verdict
This is not about "stand your ground law", it was about self defense.

The stand your ground law did not apply here (actually Zimmerman's defence team did not even A to use it as a defense). Instead they used "simple self defense" as their justification for the use of force.

So the next time a Teenage Football Player has you slammed against the pavement, broken your nose and is pummelling you "Mixed Martial Arts Style" (according to an eye witness), remember "you can feel safe knowing that they will stop before you're a seriously hurt."

The Miami Herald took a poll regarding the "stand your ground law" after this incident. There is overwhelming support for this law in Florida.

The job of a jury is not to decide the merits of a law but to apply the existing law.

This verdict demonstrates that the jury did what it was supposed to do.

Get rid of this" stand your ground law", there was no reason to use deadly force against this boy. More tragedies are bound to happen because of this law  I feel terribly sorry for this boy who lost his life and for his parents who had to through this trial. This is a crime . Justice was not served. this is a shocking verdict

These numbers don't make sense. To have driven three million miles in 47 years means driving an average of 175 miles every single day for all those years. That's four hours of driving per day, day in and day out, summer and winter. And this is a car owner who worked full time virtually around the corner from where he lives. Really?

The article also says the owner drove one million miles in the past 11 years. At highway speed on a clear road, someone would have to have driven five to six hours a day, every single day for a decade to reach that total. Five hours every single day at open road speeds. On Long Island. Really?

"..I am not sure that the majority of the members of Congress understand that austerity has put the economy on a glide path to send this economy back into a contraction." James, they know, they understand and they Do Not Care. I think it would be helpful for all of us to fully understand and fully accept that 1- they know, and 2- they Do Not Care. Only then can we actually address the problems ourselves and make progress.

The RepubliCon 'strategy' is to deflate and decrease the value of most property, goods, businesses and labor so all of same can be accumulated by a certain minority of cash rich souls. 'Tis buy low, sell high and the devil, or bankruptcy, or poor healthcare, or penury, or hunger, take the hindmost.

Gingrich named this strategy during the RepubliCon Debates -- Social Darwinism -- during a rare moment of OB-GYN-GOP truth-telling. Someone -- likely surnamed Rove or Koch -- took Newt aside. The phrase was immediately dropped and has not been employed publicly since. I'm sure, however, behind closed RepubliCon doors, it's used with satisfied amusement all the time.

Dr. K,

You are correct but I am not sure that the majority of the members of Congress understand that austerity has put the economy on a glide path to send this economy back into a contraction.

People who lost their jobs, and for many, everything, went on food stamps (SNAP) to save their homes and the means to get to work.

Many forget that most who lost their jobs and finally went back to work are employed at much lower salaries. I know plenty like that. Many of the over 50 years of age types are barely getting by. Most people do NOT want to use SNAP or extended unemployment insurance benefits, It is a miserable existence. Educated older people resent that the upper income people seem to be getting richer and the poor created by the Great Recession are remaining poor due to the high level of greed in the private sector with the cooperation of government who are focused on donors.

I also note from some of your commenters that many don't grasp what the stimulus (ARRA) was used for. It is available in a lengthy and correct rundown at
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act_of_2009

Chairman Bernanke recently said in clear, no uncertain terms, that the strongest headwind that the economic recovery is confronting is the "austerity" fiscal policies imposed by the Congress. I also note that the CBO agrees.

Repealing the Sequester should have been taken care of 3 months ago.
It isn't.
It isn't.
